newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria ex-leader freed, protests continue.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria ex-leader freed, protests continue.

text.p: Bulgaria's former communist leader Todor Zhivkov was freed from house arrest on Monday as thousands rallied for a 14th day of protests against his Socialist successors.

Sofia prosecutor Mikhail Doichev told Reuters he had issued an order for Zhivkov's release on the instructions of the chief prosecutor. "He is an old man, and in view of his health he should be free to move round town," Doichev said.
The release of Zhivkov, 85, comes at the height of severe economic and political crisis and two days before anti-communist president Zhelyu Zhelev is due to hand over to his successor Petar Stoyanov.
Students marched through Sofia on Monday with alarm clocks ringing to symbolise time running out for the Balkan country's Socialist rulers.

The Bulgarian Socialist Party (BSP) has offered elections by December, a year ahead of schedule, but is insisting on forming an interim cabinet to replace that of Zhan Videnov, who resigned on December 21.
Opposition protests received a boost on Sunday when opposition lawyer Stoyanov was sworn in as president and said elections should be held as soon as possible.

"The 14th day of our protests is different because now we have a new legitimate president and this new president is going to be our guarantee for a victory at the coming elections," opposition Union of Democratic Forces leader Ivan Kostov told the rally.
"If they don't listen to us, they will have to oppose everybody, and this is a battle that they will never win. We shall never allow a second Socialist government to rule this country," he said.
Zhelev has refused to ask the Socialists to form a new government, a task likely to be inherited by Stoyanov when he takes office on Wednesday.

If the divided Socialists fail to do so, the president must ask the other parties in parliament, and if they fail or refuse, he appoints a caretaker government, dissolves parliament, and schedules elections within two months.

At his swearing-in on Sunday, Stoyanov urged all parties to work together on measures to bring the country out of crisis, including a tough IMF-backed fixed exchange rate regime, greater financial discipline and a crackdown on corruption.

He met bankers, finance officials and other economic experts on Monday and sources at the meeting said the majority backed elections as soon as March to give a government with a firm mandate to negotiate with international lenders.
A new government is urgently needed to resume negotiations with the International Monetary Fund and avert default on Bulgaria's $10 billion foreign debt.
Zhivkov was convicted in 1992 of embezzling 21.5 million levs (then about $24 million) of public funds, spent on luxury apartments and Western cars for his family and favoured aides.
Last February the Supreme Court overturned the sentence but he still needed permission to leave his granddaughter's villa in Sofia's wealthy Boyana suburb.
Doichev said Zhivkov had to inform the prosecutor's office if he wanted to leave Sofia or change his residence.
"I haven't heard a report in the press," Zhivkov told the television. "If he has signed something it is still on its way and it will probably take two years to reach me."
Zhivkov ruled Bulgaria for 35 years until the collapse of his hardline communist regime in 1989.
A one-time associate of late Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev and Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu, he is one of Eastern Europe's last surviving communist leaders.
Despite allegations of corruption, Zhivkov remains popular among many Bulgarians nostalgic for the simpler days of one party rule when speech and movement wre restricted but basic needs were cheap.
